questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents to the ER with colicky abdominal pain. His mother tells you that he refuses to walk due to knee pain. On examination, palpable purpura is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation of palpable purpura, colicky abdominal pain, and arthritis, point towards a diagnosis of Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP) also known as IgA vasculitis.

It is a small vessel vasculitis that occurs due to IgA immune complex deposition within the wall of the blood vessels. It is commonly seen in children and is characterized by:

  • Palpable purpura without thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy.
  • Arthralgia- commonly affecting hip, knee, or ankle joints.
  • Abdominal pain
  • Glomerulonephritis: proteinuria, microscopic hematuria, RBC casts in urine.

The skin biopsy will show small vessel vasculitis, with IgA and C3 deposition in the affected organs by immunofluorescence.

Option B: Hemolytic uremic syndrome is characterized by a triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury.

Option C: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is characterized by fever of at least 2 weeks duration associated with arthritis, evanescent erythematous rash, hepatosplenomegaly, generalized lymphadenopathy, and serositis.

Option D: Patients with IgA nephropathy or Berger's disease present with gross hematuria, often associated with a preceding or ongoing viral infection of the upper respiratory tract (synpharyngitic presentation).

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented with fever, cough, dyspnea, arthralgia, and a painful rash on the lower limbs suggestive of erythema nodosum. A chest X-ray was taken and the findings are shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The chest X-ray showing bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, together with the presence of erythema nodosum, suggests the diagnosis of sarcoidosis.

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disorder of unknown etiology that is characterized by the presence of non-caseating granulomas.

In acute cases, patients may typically present with Lofgren’s syndrome, consisting of arthritis, erythema nodosum (as shown below), uveitis, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, lethargy, and occasional fever. Patients may also present with insidious onset of cough, exertional breathlessness, and radiographic infiltrates.

 

Investigation findings in sarcoidosis are as follows:

  • Lymphopenia and deranged liver function tests 
  • Hypercalcemia (due to increased synthesis of calcitriol [1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D] by alveolar macrophages) and hypercalciuria (can lead to nephrocalcinosis)
  • Pulmonary function test - the most common abnormality is an isolated decrease in diffusion of carbon monoxide (DLCO). A restrictive pattern is seen in patients with more advanced pulmonary disease. Approximately 15-20% of patients have an obstructive pattern
  • Bronchoscopy shows a typical 'cobblestone' appearance of the mucosa. Bronchial and transbronchial biopsies reveal non-caseating granulomas. An increased CD4:CD8 T-cell ratio may be seen in bronchoalveolar lavage
  • Chest X-ray is useful for staging sarcoidosis
  • HRCT shows reticulonodular opacities that follow a perilymphatic distribution centered on broncho-vascular bundles and the subpleural areas

The presence of erythema nodosum with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on chest X-ray is sufficient to make the diagnosis of sarcoidosis. A tissue biopsy is not required in this case. A typical presentation with classical HRCT features may also indicate the diagnosis. In all other cases, the diagnosis should be confirmed by histological examination of the involved organ.

A chest X-ray showing bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy in sarcoidosis is shown below,

Management of sarcoidosis is as follows:

  • Asymptomatic patients- monitored for disease progression
  • Localized/ limited cutaneous and ocular lesions- treated using topical steroids
  • Multisystem involvement:
    • Systemic steroids
    • Other drugs like hydroxychloroquine, methotrexate, and infliximab are considered when the steroids are ineffective or not tolerated

Other options:

Option A: The chest radiograph of a patient with lobar pneumonia right middle lobe is given below. Note the prominent wedge-shaped area of airspace consolidation in the right lung, which is characteristic of acute bacterial lobar pneumonia.

 

Option C: The chest radiograph given below shows extensive bilateral reticulonodular infiltrates seen in miliary tuberculosis.

 

Option D: The chest radiograph given below shows cannon-ball lesions of metastatic lung cancer.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male patient presents with retrosternal chest pain. On auscultation, a pericardial friction rub is present. Echocardiography reveals a small amount of pericardial fluid. The ECG is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient with widespread ST elevation is acute pericarditis.

Acute pericarditis is an inflammation of the pericardium characterized by retrosternal chest pain that is aggravated by deep inspiration and supine position and relieved by sitting and leaning forward. It can be attributed to various causes like infections or inflammatory conditions like RA and SLE, or miscellaneous causes like iatrogenic, neoplasms, drugs, etc.

On auscultation, 85% of patients have a pericardial friction rub. This appears as a rough scratching sound at end of expiration when the patient is sitting and leaning forward. 

ECG findings of acute pericarditis need to be differentiated from those of myocardial infarction as they are similar.

There are four stages in the development of acute pericarditis ECG changes.

  • Stage 1: Widespread elevation of ST segments; depression of PR segment below the TP segment
  • Stage 2: ST segments return to normal after a few days
  • Stage 3: T waves become inverted
  • Stage 4: ECG returns to normal after weeks or months. 

Echocardiography is diagnostic for acute pericarditis. It would reveal a small amount of pericardial fluid. It can also be confirmed by CT or MRI. 

Treatment of acute pericarditis is nonspecific. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are recommended, along with bed rest.

Other options:

Option A - Myocardial infarction would not have a pericardial friction rub. In addition, the ST changes would be localized to a specific area but in pericarditis, there are widespread changes. They would also be more prominent elevations.

Option C - Cardiac tamponade is characterized by Beck's triad of hypotension, jugulo-venous distension, and muffled heart sounds. None of these are present in this patient. 

Option D - Pulmonary embolism would be characterized by tachycardia, inverted T waves (right ventricular overload) in leads V1 - V4, and S1Q3T3 pattern would be seen.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy presented with weakness, fatigue, excessive thirst, and urination. His blood pressure was 100/76 mmHg. His lab parameters are given below. What is the diagnosis?

Urine transtubular potassium gradient (TTKG) - 8 (increased)

Urine calcium- increased

ABG analysis - metabolic alkalosis

Serum potassium - decreased (3.2 mmol/L)

Serum magnesium - decreased (0.3 mmol/L)
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of the diagnosis of Bartter syndrome.

Bartter syndrome is characterized by hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypomagnesemia (normal - 0.5 to 1 mmol/kg) and hypercalciuria with normal blood pressure. The transtubular potassium gradient (TTKG) is a physiologically based clinical test to study the renal excretion of potassium. A TTKG >4 in a patient with hypokalemia suggests excessive urinary losses of K+. 

Bartter syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder occurring due to defects in various genes involved in the regulated Na+, K+, and Cl– transport by the thick ascending loop of Henle (TALH). Each genetic defect is a subtype of Bartter syndrome. Type 3 Bartter, also known as classical Bartter is due to loss of function in CLCKNB (Chloride Voltage-Gated Channel Kb).

A defect in the Na+/K+/Cl- channel impairs the transport functions of the TALH resulting in the following features:

  • Polyuria and polydipsia
  • Marked activation of RAAS leading to increased renal loss of potassium
  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis due to bicarbonate retention
  • Hypomagnesemia in 20% of patients
  • Hypocalcemia and hypercalciuria
  • Normotensive

Antenal presentation of Bartter syndrome is characterized by polyhydramnios, premature birth, polyuria, and salt loss. Antenatal diagnosis can be made by elevated levels of chloride and aldosterone in the amniotic fluid. Antenatal Bartter can be managed by intravenous saline infusion to prevent dehydration and even death. Cyclooxygenase inhibitors are also useful in antenatal Bartter to reduce polyuria and salt wasting.

Other options:

Option A- Gitelman syndrome is due to a loss of function mutation in the thiazide sensitive Na+-Cl– cotransporter of the Distal convoluted tubule. It is characterized by hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypomagnesemia and hypocalciuria with normal blood pressure.

Option B: EAST syndrome is characterized by epilepsy, ataxia, sensorineural deafness, and tubulopathy. Biochemical abnormality is similar to Gitelman syndrome.

Option D: Liddle syndrome is due to direct increased activation of the epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) on the principal cells. Liddle's also causes hypokalemia, hypercalciuria but is characterized by severe hypertension.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: A 61-year-old man is diagnosed with non pressure hydrocephalus. An MRI brain demonstrates ventricular enlargement. After a serial lumbar puncture, his gait significantly improves. Which of the following is the best management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis is normal-pressure hydrocephalus, and MRI is showing enlarged ventricles. Ventriculo-peritoneal shunting is preferred in this condition.

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is a reversible cause of dementia. It is caused by obstruction to the normal CSF flow in the cerebral convexity and delayed absorption into the venous system.

Clinical features of NPH triad:

  • ataxia (magnetic gait is described as slow and unsteady turns that are slow, broad-based, and short-stepped)
  • dementia
  • urinary incontinence

Papilloedema is not seen.

Diagnosis: 

  • Neuroimaging reveals enlarged lateral ventricles (hydrocephalus) with little or no cortical atrophy, although the sylvian fissures can be mistaken for perisylvian atrophy due to the propped open (so-called “boxcarring”) appearance.
  • CSF parameters are normal except for the high range of pressure.
  • Another confirmatory test performed is the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) tap test which shows marked improvement of symptoms with spinal fluid removal.

Treatment: Ventriculo-peritoneal shunting- It is done to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Complications of the shunting procedure include shunt obstruction, infection, intracerebral or intraventricular hemorrhage, malposition or breakage of the shunt, etc.

Other options: 

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension presents with transient vision loss, headache, and papilledema. Medical therapy includes acetazolamide and furosemide. Topiramate is also used due to carbonic anhydrase inhibitor activity. Surgical therapy includes optic nerve sheath decompression (or optic nerve sheath fenestration) and CSF shunting procedures.

questions.text: All of the following are contraindications of LP except?

choices.text: Local skin infection at the site of LP

questions.solution:
The presence of skin infection near the site of the LP increases the risk of carrying the infection into the CSF with the LP needle. Thus, infection at the potential LP site is a contraindication to performing a lumbar puncture at that area.

Perhaps the more worrisome contraindication to lumbar puncture is the suspicion of increased intracranial pressure (ICP) due to a cerebral mass lesion. In the presence of a potential brain tumor, cerebral hemorrhage, cavernous sinus thrombosis, brain abscesses, epidural or subdural hematomas , patients are at increased risk of deteriorating neurologically with LP. As the space-occupying lesion grows, ICP rises. When lumbar puncture is performed in these patients, a low-pressure shunt is formed at the site of LP where CSF can escape.

As the CSF pressure drops in the spinal column, CSF and brain mass may then shift towards the low-pressure outlet (the LP site). This may lead to either trans-tentorial or uncal herniation and acute neurological deterioration.

Patients with increased ICP from mass lesions often display decreased levels of consciousness, focal neurological signs or papilledema on physical exam. Any of these findings make lumbar puncture contraindicated until further evaluation can be undertaken.

As with most invasive procedures, uncorrected coagulopathy is a contraindication to LP. This includes those on heparin, coumadin, or with clotting defects such as disseminated intravascular coagulation, hemophilia or thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presents with episodic headaches, sweating, and palpitations. Her blood pressure was recorded as 167/110 mmHg and lab investigations revealed elevated plasma metanephrines. An adrenal mass was seen on an abdominal CT scan and a biopsy confirms the diagnosis. Which clinical feature would you not expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with a patient having the given symptoms with elevated plasma metanephrines, and an adrenal mass is suggestive of a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma. Polyuria (not oliguria) is an expected clinical finding.

Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor derived from the chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla. 

Clinical features of pheochromocytoma are due to the autonomic effects of excess epinephrine and norepinephrine. 

  • Weight loss (option A) is due to the increase in catecholamines which increase basal metabolism.
  • Pallor (option B) is due to alpha 1-mediated vasoconstriction. 
  • Abdominal pain (option C) with nausea and vomiting is commonly seen.

Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma requires biochemical testing followed by imaging.

  • Urinary and plasma levels of catecholamines and metanephrines 
  • MRI is the investigation of choice for localizing the tumor 
  • MIBG Scintigraphy and PET Scans like Ga- DOTATE, DOPA- or FDG- PET can be used for extra-adrenal tumors and metastases

Treatment of pheochromocytoma:

Surgical resection of the tumor is the definitive treatment. Preoperatively, an alpha-receptor blocker (phenoxybenzamine) is given to control the effects produced by excess catecholamines. Beta-blockers are used to control tachycardia after adequate alpha blockade is achieved. This is to prevent unrestricted alpha-mediated vasoconstriction. Following surgery, lifelong yearly follow-ups should be done.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of Pheochromocytoma (By frequency of occurrence)

  • Clinical triad:
    • Headaches – M/C symptom
    • Profuse sweating
    • Palpitations and tachycardia
  • Hypertension, sustained or paroxysmal – M/C Sign
  • Anxiety and panic attacks
  • Weight loss
  • Polyuria and polydipsia
  • Constipation
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Erythrocytosis
  • Elevated blood sugar
  • Hypercalcemia

questions.text: A 33-year-old man collapses during a family vacation. At the hospital, blood pressure is found to be 86/52 mm Hg, and random blood sugar is 49 mg/dl. His wife says that he has been on treatment for Addison's disease two years back but had forgotten to pack his medication for the trip. What is the drug of choice for this man?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of an adrenal crisis triggered by missed medication. In this patient who is a known case of adrenal insufficiency, IV hydrocortisone is the drug of choice.

However, in patients with newly diagnosed adrenal insufficiency, dexamethasone is used for the treatment of adrenal crisis. This is because dexamethasone is not measured in cortisol assays and would not interfere with the diagnostic tests, whereas hydrocortisone interferes with cortisol assays.

Acute adrenal insufficiency requires the immediate initiation of the following therapeutic strategies:

  • Rehydration - saline infusion at an initial rate of 1 L/h with continuous cardiac monitoring.
  • Glucocorticoid replacement - bolus injection of 100 mg hydrocortisone, followed by the maintenance dose of 100–200 mg over 24h.
  • Mineralocorticoid replacement - initiated once the daily hydrocortisone dose has been reduced to <50 mg as higher doses of hydrocortisone have sufficient mineralocorticoid action.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old male patient presented with complaints of fatigue and chronic back pain. On evaluation, he was found to have anemia and hypercalcemia. The X-ray of his skull is given below. Which of the following is not seen in this patient?
  1. Plasma cells in 24-hr urine analysis
  2. Elevated Alkaline phosphatase
  3. Normocytic normochromic anemia 
  4. Osteolytic bone lesions
  5. Elevated ESR
questions.solution:
Statements 1 and 2 are incorrect/ not seen in this patient.

The given X-ray of the skull demonstrating the typical “punched out” lesions in an elderly male with chronic back pain, fatigue, anemia, and hypercalcemia are highly suggestive of multiple myeloma. It is characterized by normal serum alkaline phosphatase (due to the absence of osteoblastic activity), and plasma cells in bone marrow (not in urine).

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. It is associated with an increased osteoclast activity with suppression of osteoblast activity, causing punched-out lytic lesions in the bone and hypercalcemia.

Signs and symptoms:

  • Bone pain is the most common symptom
  • Pathologic fractures
  • Recurrent bacterial infections
  • Renal failure
  • Normocytic normochromic anemia, elevated ESR, hypercalcemia, normal ALP (ALP is a marker of bone growth and hence is not increased in multiple myeloma)
  • Radiography: Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray
  • Electrophoresis: M spikes
  • Urinalysis: Bence Jones proteinuria
  • Bone marrow biopsy: Plasma cells

Related Pearl: International Staging System (ISS) for multiple myeloma:

International Staging System (ISS) for multiple myeloma:

β2 microglobulin (mg/dL) and albumin (g/dL) level Stage Median survival months

β2M < 3.5

alb ≥3.5

 I 62

β2M < 3.5, alb < 3.5

or β2M = 3.5-5.5

 II 44
β2M > 5.5 III 29

ISS is the most widely used method of assesing prognosis in multiple myeloma.

Related Pearl: Causes of lytic lesions in the skull

Metastasis 

Eosinophilic granuloma (geographic lytic lesions in vault of skull with bevelled edges)

Lymphoma

Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (permeative lesions)

Tuberculosis

Hyperparathyroidism (salt and pepper skull)

Osteomyelitis

questions.text:
A patient with asthma is being evaluated. His FEV1 values were measured before and after the administration of a short-acting beta-agonist. Which of the following values represents the minimum change required to demonstrate the reversibility of obstruction after administration of bronchodilators in this condition?

FEV1 - Forced expiratory volume in the first minute

FVC - Forced vital capacity

choices.text: > 12% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 200 mL increase in FEV1
> 50% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 500 mL increase in FEV1
> 20% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 410 mL increase in FEV1
> 6% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 100 mL increase in FEV1

questions.solution:
Reversibility of obstruction in asthma has to be demonstrated by a minimum of 12% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 200 mL increase in FEV1 in response to inhalation of short-acting beta-agonist (SABA).

In asthma, there is reversible bronchoconstriction leading to wheezing, breathlessness, and cough. Thus, on administering an SABA, there is bronchial relaxation and relief of symptoms. 

Asthma is generally diagnosed clinically based on symptoms alone. However, some other conditions can be misdiagnosed as asthma such as causes of wheezing (bronchogenic carcinoma, foreign body aspiration), cough (gastroesophageal reflux, chronic bronchitis, rhinitis), and dyspnea (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, pulmonary edema, or obesity). Misdiagnosis would lead to a delay in management. Thus, it is ideal that the clinical diagnosis of asthma is confirmed by pulmonary function tests. 

  • Spirometry: It is a non-invasive investigation that can be used to approximate lung volumes. This shows an obstructive pattern
    • Decreased FEV1.
    • Decreased or normal FVC.
    • Decreased FEV1/FVC.
  • Bronchodilator reversibility: Spirometry is performed both before and after inhalation of a short-acting bronchodilator (400 mcg of β2 agonist or 160 mcg of anticholinergic). A 12% and 200 mL increase in FEV1 compared to pre-bronchodilator value is diagnostic of asthma in adults. 
  • Bronchial provocation test: Provocative stimulus (histamine, methacholine, inhaled mannitol, exercise, eucapnic hyperventilation with dry or cold air) is used to test the presence of airway hyperresponsiveness.  A fall of ≥20% in FEV1 from baseline, with a standard dose of methacholine (methacholine challenge test), is diagnostic of asthma.
  • Peak expiratory flow (PEF): PEF readings are taken twice daily for over 2 weeks. The average daily diurnal PEF variability of >10% is diagnostic of asthma in adults.

questions.text: Resistant hypertension is defined as?

choices.text: BP >160/90 mmHg with one anti hypertensive
BP >140/90 mmHg with one anti hypertensive
BP >160/90 mmHg with three or more anti hypertensives
BP >140/90 mmHg with three or more anti hypertensives

questions.solution:
Resistant hypertension is defined as blood pressure being persistently >140/90 mmHg despite taking three or more antihypertensive agents, including a diuretic.

Resistant hypertension is more common in patients aged >60 years than in younger patients. Resistant hypertension may be related to pseudohypertension (high office blood pressures and lower home blood pressures), nonadherence to therapy, and identifiable causes of hypertension including obesity and excessive alcohol intake.

questions.text: A 60-year-old chronic alcoholic has a distended abdomen, behavioural changes, yellowish discoloration of the skin, and decreased urine output. His laboratory investigations show elevated liver enzymes and creatinine. USG shows normal kidneys. What is the definitive treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features point to a diagnosis of hepatorenal syndrome and the definitve treatment of the same is liver transplantation. 
 
Hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) is a form of functional renal failure without any renal pathology that occurs in some patients with advanced cirrhosis or acute liver failure. The pathophysiological hallmark is severe renal vasoconstriction.
 
There are two types of HRS:
  • Type 1 HRS: There is progressive impairment in renal function and a marked decline in creatinine clearance within 1–2 weeks of presentation.
  • Type 2 HRS: There is a drop in glomerular filtration rate with elevated creatinine levels. It has a better prognosis than type 1 HRS.

Ultrasound of the kidney shows normal study and hyaline casts may be observed, indicating prerenal failure.

Management:

  • Stop diuretics
  • Albumin infusion at 1g/kg/day
  • Medical management:
    • Vasopressin analogs- terlipressin
    • Somatostatin analogs- octreotide
    • Alpha-adrenergic agonists- midodrine, noradrenaline
  • Definitive treatment: Liver transplantation 

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

Related Pearl: Indications of liver transplantation

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with an episode of sudden left-sided weakness and speech difficulty which resolved spontaneously within 24 hours. She has a history of recurrent miscarriages. ECG shows a sinus rhythm. Echocardiography revealed small vegetation on both sides of the mitral valve. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given presentation of neurological deficit resolving within 24 hours indicates a transient ischemic attack (TIA). The history of recurrent miscarriage points toward antiphospholipid syndrome (APS). These factors, along with the pattern of vegetations on the mitral valve, are strongly suggestive of Libman sack’s endocarditis.

Libman sack’s endocarditis is a type of non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE). It is associated with autoimmune conditions such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and antiphospholipid antibody syndrome. The deposition of immune complexes leads to the formation of small (1 to 4 mm), sterile vegetations on heart valves. 

Vegetations can occur anywhere on the valve surface, on the chordae, or even on the atrial or ventricular endocardium. Histologically, there is intense valvulitis and fibrinoid necrosis of the valve substance.

Patients may present with symptoms of stroke or TIA's due to emboli from the vegetation.

Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is an autoantibody-mediated acquired thrombophilia characterized by recurrent arterial or venous thrombosis and/or pregnancy morbidity. It primarily affects females. APS may either be primary or secondary to other autoimmune diseases, mainly SLE (secondary). The diagnosis of APS should be seriously considered in cases of thrombosis, cerebral vascular accidents in individuals <55 years of age, or pregnancy morbidity in the presence of livedo reticularis or thrombocytopenia. Laboratory criteria for APS include lupus anticoagulant (LA), anticardiolipin (aCL) antibody assay, and Aanti-β2GPI (glycoprotein 1) antibodies assay.

Other options:

Option A: Infective endocarditis is a microbial infection of the heart valves or the mural endocardium. The classic hallmarks of infective endocarditis are vegetations on heart valves. They are large, irregular masses on the valve cusps that can extend onto the chordae. Vegetations in infective endocarditis are friable, bulky, destructive lesions composed of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and microbes. 

Option C: Marantic endocarditis or Non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis is characterized by the deposition of small (1 to 5 mm), sterile, non-destructive thrombi along the line of closure of the leaflets of the cardiac valves. A hypercoagulable state is a predisposing factor for marantic endocarditis.

Option D: Rheumatic heart disease is the inflammation of the endocardium and the left-sided valves that typically results in fibrinoid necrosis within the cusps or tendinous cords. Vegetations in RHD are small (1-2 mm) along the lines of closures of the valve leaflets. Irregular subendocardial thickenings are termed MacCallum plaques.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman admitted to the surgical ward had been diagnosed with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. Which of the following is not a suitable next step for this patient?
questions.solution:
Switching to warfarin is not a suitable next step for patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). 

Warfarin should not be administered in HIT until platelets return to their baseline level. If warfarin was administered, give vitamin K to restore the INR to normal. 

Patients with HIT, particularly those with associated thrombosis, have increased thrombin generation that can lead to consumption of protein C. If these patients are given warfarin without a concomitant parenteral anticoagulant to inhibit thrombin or thrombin generation, the further decrease in protein C levels induced by the vitamin K antagonist can trigger skin necrosis.

HIT is a life-threatening complication of exposure to heparin. It occurs more with unfractionated heparin than with low molecular weight (LMW) heparin. It is more common in surgical patients and more common in women than in men.

HIT results from an autoantibody directed against endogenous platelet factor 4 (PF4) in complex with heparin. These antibodies bind simultaneously to the heparin-PF4 complex and to platelet Fc receptors, activating the platelets and generating platelet microparticles. This can cause catastrophic arterial and venous thrombosis.

Features:

  • Thrombocytopenia: Platelet count of ≤100,000/μL or a decrease in platelet count of ≥50%
  • Platelet count falls 5–10 days after starting heparin.
  • Venous thrombosis more common than arterial thrombosis

Investigations:

  1. ELISA to detect antibodies against heparin-PF4 complexes (most sensitive)
  2. Platelet activation assays
  3. Serotonin release assay (most specific)

Treatment:

  1. Stop all heparin.
  2. Give an alternative anticoagulant, such as lepirudin, argatroban, bivalirudin, fondaparinux or rivaroxaban.
  3. Do not give platelet transfusions.

Other options: 

Option A - Heparin should be discontinued if the patient has HIT. 

Option B - Lepirudin can be administered as it is an alternative anticoagulant. 

Option D - Rivaroxaban can be given as it is an alternative anticoagulant.

questions.text: The given image is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts a classical fish mouth (microstomia) appearance seen in systemic sclerosis/scleroderma.

Scleroderma or Systemic Sclerosis (SSc) is an autoimmune rheumatic disease in which there is a 4:1 female predominance.

A wide spectrum of clinical features are seen in Scleroderma:

  • Severe pruritus
  • Initially, puffiness and non-pitting edema of fingers
  • The skin later becomes indurated, thickened, and fixed to underlying structures resulting in sclerodactyly
  • Vasospasm and digital ulceration
  • Most patients have dysphagia and GERD
  • Mask-like facies is seen due to the waxy nature of skin and lack of wrinkles, expressionless facies, mat‐like telangiectases, microstomia, perioral furrowing, and beak‐like nose.

The antibodies tested in systemic sclerosis include:

  • Antinuclear antibody (ANA) - positive in most cases of systemic sclerosis. The absence of this antibody suggests considering an alternate diagnosis.
  • Anticentromere antibody (ACA) - usually positive in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis
  • Antitopoisomerase I (anti-Scl-70) antibody - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis 
  • Anti-RNA polymerase III antibody - usually positive with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

Other options:

Option B: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease that most commonly presents with arthralgia with early morning stiffness. Other important features of SLE include malar rash, discoid rash, photosensitivity, oral ulcers, pleuritis, pericarditis, and lupus nephritis. ANA, Anti-dsDNA antibodies, and anti-Smith antibodies are positive in SLE. 

Option C: Angular stomatitis is the soreness at the angles of the mouth extending outwards in the folds of the facial skin.

Option D: Hand-foot-and-mouth disease is caused by coxsackievirus. It is an exanthematous fever affecting mainly young children, characterized by oral and pharyngeal ulcerations and a vesicular rash of the palms and soles that may spread to the arms and legs.

questions.text:
Match the following:
  1. First-degree heart block
  2. Mobitz type 1 heart block
  3. Mobitz type 2 heart block
  4. Complete heart block
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are 1- c, 2- a, 3- d, and 4- b.

The different types of heart blocks are:

First Degree Heart Block: It occurs due to slowing of conduction through the AV junction. It is characterized by prolonged PR > 0.2s and equal RR intervals.

 

Second Degree Heart Block: It occurs due to the intermittent failure of electrical impulse conduction from the atrium to the ventricle. It is characterized by a missed QRS. It is of two types:

  • Mobitz type 1/ Wenckebach occurs due to the decremental conduction of electrical impulses in the AV node. It is characterized by a progressive PR elongation leading to an eventual drop in the QRS complex. This may be seen in young athletes.

 

  • Mobitz type 2 occurs in the distal or infra-His conduction system and is often associated with intraventricular conduction delays.  It is characterized by an intermittent failure of conduction of the p wave without any change in the preceding impulses. On ECG there is a fixed PR interval and missed QRS.

 

Third Degree Heart Block/Complete Heart Block

It occurs when none of the impulses from the atria are conducted to the ventricles. It is characterized by

  • Escape rhythm
  • RR equal, PP equal
  • P waves > QRS waves
  • No relationship between P & QRS

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

questions.text:
A 23-year-old patient presents with nausea, vomiting, and low-grade fever for a week and developed jaundice yesterday. On abdominal examination, he has tenderness in the right upper quadrant. His laboratory evaluation is given below. What is the management for his condition?
IgM Anti-HAV positive
HBsAg negative
HBeAg negative
Anti-HBs positive
S.aminotransferases elevated
questions.solution:
This patient with gastrointestinal symptoms and positive IgM- HAV is likely to have acute hepatitis A infection and requires supportive treatment. 

Since most patients recover spontaneously, only supportive treatment is required. 

Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is an icosahedral, non enveloped virus that causes hepatitis A infection. HAV is transmitted by the fecal-oral route. Usually, it is due to contamination of food or water. It may transmit from person to person due to poor hygiene. It mostly is of mild nature, with only 0.1% of patients developing fulminant hepatitis.

It has an incubation period of 15 - 45 days. It may present with constitutional symptoms of nausea, vomiting, anorexia, malaise, myalgia, arthralgia, headache, and photophobia. 1-2 weeks after the constitutional symptoms, patients present with jaundice and tender hepatomegaly. Low-grade fever may also be present. 

This is followed by a recovery phase where the constitutional symptoms disappear but the hepatomegaly and elevated transaminases are still present. Full recovery is expected 1-2 months after the onset. 

Diagnosis of HAV is confirmed by IgM anti-HAV during acute illness. 

It can be prevented by HAV vaccination.

Other options:

Option B - Antivirals are not needed in HAV. They may be used in hepatitis B or C. 

Option C - Physical isolation is done in hepatitis A patients with fecal incontinence. This patient does not have fecal incontinence. Even then, HAV is excreted in feces in very small amounts. Using gloves to handle fecal matter is sufficient.

Option D - Interferon therapy is useful in the treatment of chronic HCV and HBV infections. They are cytokines that have antiviral, immunomodulatory, and antiproliferative activity.

questions.text: A middle-aged man, who smokes around 8-9 cigarettes per day for the past 15 years presented with chronic cough and breathlessness. Initially, breathlessness was mild, but now it has gradually affected his day-to-day activities. A pulmonary function test showed FEV1/FVC to be 0.65 and FEV1 is 75% of the predicted value. What is the severity of the disease?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical vignette, the patient is a chronic smoker and has chronic progressive breathlessness, along with chronic cough. The diagnosis is likely to be chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. According to Gold's criteria, the severity of the disease in this patient is moderate.

The severity of COPD is assessed by using the Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) criteria. In pulmonary function testing, a postbronchodilator FEV1/FVC ratio of <0.70 is considered diagnostic for COPD. 

The Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease (GOLD) system categorizes COPD into following stages,

GOLD Stage

Severity

Spirometry

In patients with FEV1/FVC <0.7

GOLD I

Mild

FEV1 ≥80% predicted

GOLD II

Moderate

FEV1 ≥50% but <80% predicted

GOLD III

Severe

FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted

GOLD IV

Very severe

FEV1 <30% predicted

Note: FEV1/FVC is measured after the administration of a bronchodilator.

questions.text: An elderly woman has chronic pain in the small joints of hands with a stiffness of joints in the early hours of the day. The image of the patient’s hands is given below. She has been treated with methotrexate and low-dose corticosteroids for 3 months. But the disease is still progressing. What would you recommend for further management of this patient?

choices.text: Stop oral methotrexate and start parenteral methotrexate

questions.solution:
The clinical history and image are suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis. Combination therapy of methotrexate, sulfasalazine, and hydroxychloroquine (oral triple therapy) is indicated in the management of rheumatoid arthritis when the patient is not responding to methotrexate alone.

Joints commonly affected in rheumatoid arthritis: (bilateral and symmetrically involvement) 

  • MCP joints
  • Wrists
  • PIP joints
  • MTP joints

DMARDS, glucocorticoids, and biologicals are used in the management of rheumatoid arthritis (RA):

DMARDs (Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs): They are the mainstay of treatment. Methotrexate is the drug of choice in patients with RA. It can be used alone (in low disease activity) or with a 3-drug combination (in high disease activity) with other DMARDs such as hydroxychloroquine, sulfasalazine, and leflunomide (reserve drug).

Glucocorticoids: Mainly given in active disease. May be administered in low to moderate doses to achieve rapid disease control before the onset of fully effective DMARD therapy, which often takes several weeks or even months. Second, 1-2 week bursts of glucocorticoids may be prescribed for the management of acute disease flares.

Biologicals: They are protein therapeutics designed mostly to target cytokines and cell-surface molecules. They are indicated when the disease is not responding to two or more DMARDs. They include:

  • Anti-TNF alpha agents: Infliximab, etanercept, adalimumab, golimumab, and certolizumab. Side effects include increased risk of infections, reactivation of latent TB, drug-induced SLE, malignancy, and hepatitis B flares.
  • Anakinra: IL-1 antagonist
  • Tocilizumab: IL-6 antagonist
  • Abatacept: Inhibits co-stimulation of T cells
  • Rituximab: Anti CD-20
  • Tofacitinib: JAK 3 inhibitor

questions.text: On auscultation of a patient, a murmur was heard which is depicted by the following phonocardiogram. Which of the given conditions is most likely to produce this murmur?
questions.solution:
The phonocardiogram given above is of an ejection systolic murmur, which is seen in aortic stenosis. It is also heard in pulmonary stenosis. They are differentiated based on the difference in symptoms, site of murmur, etc.

 Clinical findings in aortic stenosis:

  • Pulse - slow rising and late peaking pulse which is known as pulsus parvus et tardus. A carotid thrill may also be palpated over these arteries.
  • Apical impulse - A double apical impulse may be recognized, and in the later stages, it may be displaced laterally.

Auscultation findings in aortic stenosis:

  • Early systolic ejection sound - heard in early stages, disappears when the valve becomes calcified and rigid
  • Paradoxical splitting of S2 - With worsening of stenosis, delayed closure of the aortic valve occurs. This leads to narrowing of S2 sound, and in severe cases, leads to paradoxical splitting of S2.
  • S4 and S3 - heard in severe cases
  • Ejection systolic murmur - starts after S1, increases in intensity to reach the peak, and ends before A2. It radiates to the neck and base of the heart. It is augmented by squatting and reduced by the strain of the Valsalva maneuver.

The image below shows phonocardiograms of normal and abnormal heart sounds.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with watery diarrhea for the past few weeks that did not respond to medication along with frequent epigastric pain, bloating, and indigestion. Stool culture was negative but he was found to have microcytic hypochromic anemia and his serum K+ was 2.9 mmol/L. Upper GI endoscopy was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes watery diarrhea, hypokalemia (serum K+<3.5 mM), and symptoms of achlorhydria (bloating, indigestion, iron deficiency) which suggests the diagnosis of WDHA syndrome caused by VIPoma.

VIPoma is pancreatic endocrine neoplasia. The tumor secretes vasoactive intestinal peptides which are responsible for the secretory watery diarrhea and other symptoms mentioned above. While suspecting a case of VIPoma it is essential to conduct a VIP assay so as to confirm the presence of other tumors of neural crest origin such as neuroblastoma or pheochromocytoma. 

Diagnosis can be made by the demonstration of an elevated plasma VIP level and the history of large-volume diarrhea.

Other options: 

Option A: Gastrinoma is a neuroendocrinal tumor characterized by hypersecretion of gastrin resulting in gastrointestinal tract ulcers. The most common presentations of gastrinoma are epigastric pain, diarrhea, and peptic ulcers. The ulcers occur at typical locations (proximal duodenum) and atypical locations (distal duodenum, jejunum). However, in this scenario, the endoscopy findings were normal.

Option C: Delta cell tumor, aka somatostatinoma, is also a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor presents with cholelithiasis, diarrhea, neurofibromatosis.

Option D: Pancreatic carcinoid is associated with excess serotonin and presents with sweating, flushing, diarrhea, and edema.

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Syndrome

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms
  • Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.
  • In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: You are on duty in the gastroenterology department as a second-year resident, evaluating patients for upper and lower gastrointestinal lesions. What will be your diagnosis of the following images?

choices.text: A- Barrett's esophagus, B- Mallory Weiss tear
A- Mallory Weiss tear, B- Barrett's esophagus
A- Crohn’s Disease, B- Ulcerative Colitis
A- Ulcerative Colitis, B- Crohn’s Disease

questions.solution:
Image A shows ulcerative colitis and image B shows Crohn's disease.

The given image A shows continuous involvement of mucosa with no normal mucosa in between, which indicates ulcerative colitis. 

Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease resulting in superficial erosions confined to the mucosa and submucosa of the colon. It starts from the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous manner.

Colonoscopy shows loss of typical vascular pattern, granularity, friability, and ulceration involving the distal rectum, extending proximally in symmetric, continuous, and circumferential patterns. Fistula is not a complication of ulcerative colitis. 

Image B shows a cobblestone appearance seen in Crohn's disease. Normal mucosa in between the ulcers leads to this appearance. Fine granular mucosa is the earliest barium enema finding in Ulcerative colitis. Fistula is seen with Crohn’s disease.

Crohn's disease may occur in any area of the GI tract, but the most common sites involved at presentation are the terminal ileum, ileocecal valve, and cecum. It is associated with smoking.

 In Crohn's disease, the following are seen:

  • Aphthous ulcers - Small, shallow ulcers surrounded by erythema
  • Longitudinal ulcers - Linear or serpiginous deep ulcers 
  • Cobblestone appearance - Deep, longitudinal ulcerations interlaced with intervening normal mucosa
  • Strictures 
  • Fistulas

Other options:

Barrett's esophagus is a condition in which the mucosal lining of the swallowing tube that connects the mouth to the stomach (esophagus) becomes damaged by acid reflux, which causes the lining to thicken and become red. It is associated with an increased risk of developing esophageal cancer.

 

Mallory Weiss tear is due to a longitudinal tear in mucosa or submucosa of the gastroesophageal junction. It is most commonly seen in alcoholics, following forceful vomiting, retching, coughing, or staining. The left gastric artery is the most common vessel to bleed. The investigation of choice is endoscopy.

questions.text: A man who sustained a crush injury during an earthquake was rescued. His blood pressure was stable and no internal bleeding was detected. A significant reduction in his urine output was noted after some time. Investigations showed urine/plasma creatinine ratio < 20 and urinary sodium of 50 mEq/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette given is intrinsic acute kidney injury (AKI). The history of crush injury is suggestive of rhabdomyolysis leading to AKI.

AKI is defined as a decline in kidney function within 7 days, resulting in the accumulation of nitrogenous waste and other toxic metabolites usually excreted in the urine. It includes a variety of conditions that share some common features such as elevated creatinine levels and reduced urine output. It is broadly divided into three categories:

  • Prerenal azotemia 
  • Intrinsic parenchymal disease
  • Postrenal obstruction

Intrinsic causes can further be divided into acute tubular necrosis, acute glomerulonephritis, and acute interstitial nephritis. Ischemia and nephrotoxins are the main causes of acute tubular necrosis. Nephrotoxins can be exogeneous such as vancomycin, cisplatin, and iodinated contrast agents used for CT imaging. Endogenous toxins include myoglobin, uric acid, and hemoglobin. Crush injuries, heat stroke, and myopathies can result in rhabdomyolysis releasing large amounts of myoglobin. The urine/plasma creatinine ratio is usually ≤ 40.

In acute tubular necrosis, urinary sodium is >20 mEq/L. 

Prerenal azotemia arises due to a reduced renal plasma flow. Common causes include hypovolemia, liver failure, and congestive heart failure. The urine/plasma creatinine ratio is ≥ 40 and urinary sodium is usually <20mEq/L.

Bladder outlet obstruction, urethral obstruction, and benign prostatic hyperplasia lead to postrenal azotemia. Urinary sodium can be variable.

More causes of AKI are given below:

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, and wheezing for 4 weeks. Absolute eosinophil count >5000/μL. Chest  X-ray shows a miliary pattern. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features along with elevated absolute eosinophil count and miliary pattern in chest x-ray are suggestive of tropical pulmonary eosinophilia.

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (TPE) is a hyperresponsive pulmonary syndrome that occurs in response to trapped microfilariae within the lung parenchyma. It is a type 1 hypersensitivity reaction.

Clinical features:

The patient has a history of residence in a filaria endemic area and usually presents with nocturnal paroxysmal wheeze and cough. Other manifestations include weight loss, low-grade fever, and lymphadenopathy. Hepatosplenomegaly may be seen due to the trapping of microfilariae in the reticuloendothelial system.

Investigations:

  • Eosinophilia > 3000/μL, leucocytosis
  • X-ray chest: Mottled opacities or miliary lesions in the middle and lower lung fields, increased bronchovascular markings
  • PFT: Restrictive changes in most cases and obstructive defects in half
  • Elevated levels of IgE and Antifilarial antibody titers
  • Microfilaria are sequestrated in the lungs and hence not found in blood

Treatment: Diethylcarbamazine(DEC) at a daily dosage of 4-6 mg/kg for 14 days.

 Differntial Diagnosis:

  • Bronchial asthma
  • Loffler syndrome
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis
  • Churg strauss syndrome
  • Chronic eosinophilic pneumonia
  • Hypereosinophilic syndromes

Other options:

Option A:  The classical symptoms of bronchial asthma are wheezing, dyspnea, and cough which is worse at night and keeps the patient awake in the early morning hours. Chest auscultation reveals rhonchi throughout the chest. The chest x-ray is usually normal but hyperinflation may be seen in severe patients.

Option B: Miliary TB occurs due to the hematogenous spread of tubercle bacilli. Clinical features are nonspecific and depend on the site of involvement. Common manifestations include fever, night sweats, anorexia, weakness, and weight loss. Blood investigations may reveal anemia with leukopenia, lymphopenia, neutrophilic leukocytosis, leukemoid reactions, and polycythemia. Chest x-ray shows a miliary reticulonodular pattern in some cases.

Option D: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis, also known as extrinsic allergic alveolitis, is an inflammatory response to various inhaled antigens. The clinical presentation can be acute, subacute, and chronic. History of exposure to the offending antigen is present. Chest x-ray findings are nonspecific and can show ground-glass opacities or ill-defined micronodular opacities.

questions.text: A patient presented with sinusitis, ulcerative lesions on the nasopharynx, nodular lesions with cavitations of the lung, and renal failure. Which of the following is used to diagnose this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given patient has the involvement of upper respiratory tract (chronic sinusitis, ulcerations on nasopharynx), lower respiratory tract (nodular lesions with lung cavitations), and kidneys (renal failure) which are suggestive of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's granulomatosis) and testing for cytoplasmic ANCA (c-ANCA) would be the most helpful investigation in this condition.

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis is a granulomatous and necrotizing vasculitis of the small arteries and veins that mainly affects:

  • Upper respiratory tract: chronic sinusitis, serous otitis media due to eustachian tube blockage, nasal septal perforation, and mucosal ulceration of the nasopharynx.
  • Lower respiratory tract: presenting with cough, hemoptysis, dyspnea, and persistent pneumonitis. Lung involvement typically appears as multiple, bilateral nodular cavitary infiltrates.
  • Kidneys: focal or segmental glomerulonephritis presenting with proteinuria, hematuria, and hypertension. If left untreated it can lead to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

Apart from these organs, it can also affect the eyes and skin. Skin lesions present as palpable purpura or subcutaneous nodules.

Lab investigations will show anemia, leucocytosis, elevated ESR, and high titers of cytoplasmic ANCA (c-ANCA) targetted against anti-proteinase-3 (anti-PR-3). The specificity of a positive PR-3 ANCA for Wegener's is very high, especially in the presence of active glomerulonephritis. Following treatment, PR-3 ANCA titers fall and subsequent rise in titers is predictive of relapse. Chest radiograph will show multiple, bilateral cavitating nodules and pulmonary infiltrates.

The diagnosis is confirmed by the presence of necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis on biopsy. This finding is commonly seen in the tissues obtained from the lungs, upper airways, skin, and rarely in the kidneys.

The radiograph below shows cavitating nodules in a patient with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's).

The antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are the antibodies that are targeted against the specific proteins present in neutrophils and monocytes. They can be further classified as:

 

Cytoplasmic ANCA (cANCA)

 Perinuclear ANCA (pANCA)

Directed against

Proteinase 3

 Myeloperoxidase

Predominantly positive in

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis)

Microscopic polyangiitis

Churg–Strauss syndrome 

Crescentic glomerulonephritis

Staining pattern

Granular cytoplasmic staining

Perinuclear or nuclear staining

Related Pearl: Autoantibodies Seen in Autoimmune Diseases

         Autoantibody Associated disease
Antinuclear (ANA)

SLE (non-specific)
Anticardiolipin lupus anticoagulant SLE, APLA syndrome
Anti-ds DNA, anti-smith SLE
Anti-histone Drug-induced Lupus

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with amenorrhea, headache,  vomiting, loss of libido, and galactorrhea from 3 months. On examination, her vitals are within range but her eye examination shows bitemporal hemianopia. Which of the following drug is preferred in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of prolactinoma of the pituitary. Among the given options, cabergoline is the preferred drug for this patient.

Prolactinoma: Prolactin-secreting lactotroph adenomas are the most frequent type of hyperfunctioning pituitary adenomas. The symptoms include

  • Headache and vomiting
  • Bitemporal hemianopia suggestive of a local mass effect
  • Increased intracranial pressure due to a pituitary tumor
  • In females- amenorrhea, galactorrhea, loss of libido, and infertility
  • In males- impotence, loss of libido, and gynecomastia

The diagnosis of prolactinoma is most likely to be associated with a prolactin level >200 μg/L.

Treatment is only required in symptomatic cases as microadenomas rarely progress to macroadenomas. The mainstay of treatment is medical management. Dopamine and dopamine agonists are used and they act as inhibitory signals to prolactin secretion in the pituitary. 

Cabergoline is a long-acting dopamine receptor agonist with high D2 receptor affinity and is the preferred drug for the treatment of hyperprolactinemia because of its greater efficacy and lower side effects. It effectively suppresses prolactin secretion for >14 days after a single oral dose. At higher doses, it is used in some patients with acromegaly, alone or along with somatostatin analogs.

Another drug used in prolactinoma is bromocriptine. It is shorter-acting when compared with cabergoline. The adverse effects of bromocriptine include hypotension and nausea. 

Related Pearl: Classification of Pituitary Adenomas with Associated Syndromes

Mammosomatotroph adenoma

GH: Growth hormone

ACTH: Adrenocorticotropic hormone

questions.text: A patient with diabetes, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease has elevated serum creatinine and urea levels. Which of the following oral hypoglycemic agents is safe to use?
questions.solution:
Linagliptin does not require dose adjustment in patients with renal failure and is safe to use in this patient.

Linagliptin is a dipeptidyl-peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. It is used in type 2 diabetes as monotherapy or in combination therapy when metformin is not tolerated or contraindicated. It binds extensively to plasma proteins and is cleared primarily by the hepatobiliary system. Hence, no dosage adjustment is needed in renal failure.

Other DPP-4 inhibitors (sitagliptin, vildagliptin, saxagliptin, alogliptin) show renal elimination and therefore require dose reduction and caution in renal failure. (Option C)

Other options:

Option B: GLP-1 agonists are dependent on renal clearance and therefore should not be given to patients with moderate to severe renal failure.

Option C: The use of glimepiride is not recommended in patients with chronic kidney disease, especially stage 4 or 5.

questions.text:
Which of the following indicate a good prognosis in children diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia?
  1. Age < 1 year
  2. Mild hepatosplenomegaly
  3. Hyperdiploidy
  4. Female sex
  5. WBC count < 50,000 per mm3
questions.solution:
In children with ALL, a good prognosis is indicated by low WBC count, female sex, and hyperdiploidy.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient presented with electric shock-like sensations that go down her legs, from two days. She has a history of sensory loss over her face that resolved without treatment a few months back. One year ago, she had decreased visual acuity for one day which then resolved. Her T2-weighted MRI is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is multiple sclerosis (MS). 

The MRI given depicts Dawson's fingers which are areas of perivenous demyelination that are seen as lesions that are perpendicular to the ventricle. They appear as hyperintense areas on the T2-weighted images.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease characterized by inflammation, multiple demyelinating plaques, and relapsing and remitting symptoms. It occurs due to infiltration of the white matter by T cells and macrophages leading to axonal damage and neurodegeneration. It presents abruptly or insidiously with variable intensity of symptoms depending on the location. 

The most common symptoms experienced are as follows:

  1. Sensory symptoms:
    1. Paresthesia, pins and needles sensations, hypoesthesia
    2. Horizontal cut-off on limbs for sensory involvement suggests lesions at the level of the spinal cord 
    3. Pain
  2. Optic neuritis:
    1. Reduced visual acuity, color perception, dimness in the central visual field, unilaterally or bilaterally.
    2. Periorbital pain
    3. Funduscopy: optic disc swelling, pallor
  3. Weakness of limbs
    1. Loss of strength, speed, dexterity
    2. Gait disturbance
    3. Upper motor neuron weakness
    4. Pyramidal signs: spasticity, hyperreflexia
    5. Babinski sign positive
  4. Facial weakness 
  5. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia - bilaterally
  6. Ataxia, vertigo

Paroxysmal symptoms may occur, characterized by short duration and high-frequency occurrence per day. These can manifest as:

  • Lhermitte's sign - electric shock-like sensations that go down legs or back on neck flexion
  • Uthoff symptom -neurological symptoms produced by elevated core body temperature
  • Tonic seizures and dysarthria
  • Trigeminal neuralgia, and facial myokymia 
  • Bladder dysfunction as detrusor hyperreflexia or detrusor sphincter dyssynergia
  • Fatigue

MS can have three different clinical courses: 

  1. Relapsing or bout onset (90%) of cases. Here, there is complete recovery between episodes. As the disease progresses, the recovery may not be complete. 
  2. Secondary progressive MS starts as relapsing MS but then experiences decreased function as a result of the attacks.
  3. Primary progressive MS (10% of the cases) has a consistent decline in function from disease onset. They do not have discrete episodes. 

Diagnosis of MS requires at least two or more episodes of symptoms and two or more signs that show the involvement of noncontiguous white matter tracks. The symptoms must last for at least one day and must be separated chronologically by one month. 

MRI demonstrates increased vascular permeability and multifocal hyperintense lesions. Dawson's fingers may be present. The cerebrospinal fluid examination will show mononuclear cell pleocytosis and increased IgG. 

Other options: 

Option A - Thalamic stroke is usually unilateral and is characterized by hemi-sensory disturbance throughout the body. 

Option C - Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by extreme episodic pain affecting the area of the face supplied by the trigeminal nerve except for the ophthalmic division. It is of sudden onset and short duration, lasting up to a few minutes. 

Option D - Neuromyelitis optical (NMO) is characterized by recurrent optic neuritis and transverse myelitis. It is similar in presentation to MS except that NMO is severe, bilateral, and can cause severe visual loss. Myelitis usually involves three or more contiguous vertebral segments. NMO does not have progressive symptoms in contrast to MS.

questions.text: A 57-year-old unresponsive male patient is brought to the hospital. He is pulseless and is not breathing. His lead II ECG rhythm strip is shown in the image below. What is the treatment for the given ECG abnormality?
questions.solution:
The ECG with no identifiable P wave, QRS complexes, and irregular rhythm is ventricular fibrillation (VF) and the treatment is defibrillation. 

Ventricular fibrillation is a disorganized ventricular rhythm. In a heart with ventricular fibrillation, there is little to no cardiac output as there is irregular cardiac contraction. In patients outside the hospital, sustained ventricular tachycardias are a common cause leading to ventricular fibrillation.

VF is a shockable rhythm. Thus, defibrillation must be performed in order to restore normal sinus rhythm according to advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) guidelines. In defibrillation, an electrical current is passed into the myocardium which 'resets' it by converting the dysrhythmia into a normal sinus rhythm. 

When the timing of electric current is adjusted according to the R waves or the QRS complex of the cardiac cycle, it is known as synchronized shock, which is administered in cardioversion. In ventricular fibrillation, because of irregular cardiac electrical activity, there are no R waves or QRS complexes to which the cardioversion can be synchronized. Hence, it is administered unsynchronized to the cardiac cycle.

 

Other options:

Option A - Magnesium sulfate is used to treat torsades de points. It is a type of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. 

Options C and D - Synchronised cardioversion and rate control are used to treat atrial fibrillation (AF). AF has normal QRS complexes with variable atrial activity resulting in irregular P waves of varying morphology.

The below ECG depicts atrial fibrillation:

Related Pearl: Adult cardiac arrest algorithm (Updated as per 2020 guidelines)

questions.text: As a healthcare worker working in a COVID hospital, you receive the following vaccine. Which of the following is not an adverse event related to this vaccine?
questions.solution:
Demyelinating disorders are rare adverse events following Covishield, not Covaxin.

Composition of Covaxin:

  • Inactivated coronavirus
  • Aluminum hydroxide gel
  • TLR 7/8 agonist
  • 2-Phenoxyethanol and
  • Phosphate Buffered Saline/ NKA1

 Adverse effects:

 Covaxin Covishield

Fever, cough, sweating

 Fever and chills

Injection site pain and swelling

 Injection site pain and swelling

Headache, bodyache, fatigue

 Headache, malaise, fatigue

Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting

 Nausea

Dizziness, giddiness, tremor

Myalgia, arthralgia

Rarely, complications like demyelinating disorders, Guillain-Barre syndrome, and vaccine-induced immune thrombotic thrombocytopenia (VITT) are also seen following Covishield vaccine.

questions.text: All the following are components of the Kartagener's triad except ________
questions.solution:
Male infertility is typical in Kartagener syndrome, but not a component of the triad.

The primary defect in Kartagener’s Syndrome is primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD). i.e. immotility of cilia. Patients with PCD have the Kartagener triad, characterized by:

  • Situs inversus totalis
  • Bronchiectasis
  • Chronic sinusitis

Defects in ciliary motor proteins lead to ciliary dysfunction. This causes the retention of secretions due to a failed mucociliary clearance mechanism. Clinically, this manifests as chronic sinusitis and recurrent infections that ultimately lead to bronchiectasis.

questions.text:
A middle-aged woman presents with heat intolerance and fine tremors in both her hands for 6 months. She also complains of palpitations, weight loss, and menstrual irregularities. Examination revealed a BP of 136/86 mm Hg, tachycardia, and exophthalmos. Which of the statements is true in this patient?

RAIU - Radioactive Iodine Uptake

choices.text: RAIU at 24 hours is below normal

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient's symptoms point toward hyperthyroidism, and eye findings like exophthalmos are highly suggestive of Graves' disease. In this condition, the serum TSH is low, unbound T4 is high, and T3 is high. 

Graves disease is an autoimmune disease with a strong familial predisposition (50%) and females are at a higher risk with a peak incidence between the ages of 40-60 years. The most common cause of hyperthyroidism is due to stimulatory autoantibodies i.e Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI) to TSH-R. Thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI) binds to and activates the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptor resulting in diffuse toxic goiter and therefore, increased T4 and T3 levels. The clinical features include:

Symptoms:

  • Hyperactivity,  irritability, dysphoria
  • Heat intolerance and sweating
  • Palpitations
  • Fatigue and weakness
  • Weight loss with increased appetite
  • Diarrhea
  • Polyuria
  • Oligomenorrhea,  loss of libido

Signs:

  • Tachycardia, atrial fibrillation in the elderly
  • Tremor
  • Goiter
  • Warm, moist skin
  • Muscle weakness, proximal myopathy
  • Lid retraction or lag
  • Gynecomastia
  • Extra thyroidal conditions include ophthalmopathy, dermopathy (pretibial myxedema), thyroid acropachy, gynecomastia, and other manifestations.

Diagnosis:

  • Lab Investigations:
    • T4 and T3 increased due to the stimulating effect of TSI on the TSH receptors.
    • TSH is reduced as increased T4 levels in the blood lead to negative feedback on TRH in the hypothalamus.
    • Elevated TSH-R antibodies- diagnostic
    • Anti-Tg and anti-TPO are seen but nonspecific
  • Radiological investigations:
    • RAIU (radioactive iodine uptake) at 24 hours is characteristically above normal due to increased thyroid hormone production.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding transfusion-related acute lung injury?

choices.text: High titres of HLA antibodies in donor plasma
Nulliparous women are the implicated donors
Patient presents with non- cardiogenic pulmonary edema

questions.solution:
In cases of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI), the implicated donors are frequently multiparous women. It may occur in any recipient.

TRALI usually results from the transfusion of donor plasma that contains high-titer anti-HLA class II antibodies that bind recipient WBCs. The WBCs aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release mediators that increase capillary permeability. TRALI is one of the most common causes of transfusion-related fatalities. The recipient develops symptoms of hypoxia and signs of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema, including bilateral interstitial infiltrates on chest x-ray, either during or within 6 hours of transfusion. 

Recipient factors that are associated with increased risk of TRALI include

  • smoking
  • chronic alcohol use
  • shock, liver surgery
  • mechanical ventilation with >30 cmH2O pressure support.

Treatment is supportive and patients usually recover without sequelae.

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions is/are not associated with secondary Raynaud's phenomenon?
  1. Systemic lupus erythematosus
  2. Scleroderma
  3. Buerger disease
  4. Raynaud's disease
  5. Atherosclerosis
questions.solution:
Raynaud’s disease is a primary Raynaud's phenomenon, and all others are associated with secondary Raynaud's phenomenon.

Raynaud's Phenomenon refers to exaggerated vasoconstriction of arteries and arterioles in the extremities, particularly the fingers and toes, but also occasionally the nose, earlobes, or lips.

The restricted blood flow induces paroxysmal pallor, and even cyanosis in severe cases. The involved digits classically show red, white, and blue color changes from the most proximal to most distal regions. This correlates with proximal vasodilation, central vasoconstriction, and more distal cyanosis.

Raynaud phenomenon can be a primary entity or secondary to other disorders.

Primary Raynaud

Secondary Raynaud

Caused by exaggerated central and local vasomotor responses to cold or emotion.

Has a predilection for young women.

Results from vascular insufficiency due to arterial disease.

Raynaud disease

Systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, Buerger disease, atherosclerosis

Symmetrically affects the extremities

Asymmetric involvement of the extremities

The severity and extent of involvement typically remain static over time

Progressively worsens in extent and severity over time

questions.text: A 53-year-old female patient presents with complaints of weakness for the last 2 months. Additionally, she is facing difficulty rising from a chair, and combing her hair every morning. A physical exam reveals decreased strength in the shoulders and hip. Skin findings are as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical vignette, this patient's symptoms along with the image findings showing heliotrope rash are highly suggestive of dermatomyositis. Dermatomyositis involves CD 4+ cells, perimyseal infiltrates, and is associated with underlying malignancy. 

Dermatomyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy characterized by proximal skeletal muscle weakness, muscle inflammation, and a variety of characteristic skin manifestations. The pattern of muscle involvement helps distinguish a myopathy from a cerebral, spinal cord, neuronal or neuromuscular junction cause. It is commonly associated with an underlying malignancy.

Classic signs-

  • Heliotrope rash/ eyelid erythema- Violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids
  • V sign- Confluent macular erythema over the lower anterior neck and upper anterior chest
  • Shawl sign- Confluent macular erythema over the upper back and lateral aspect of arms
  • Gottron’s papules- Erythematous papules and plaques over extensor surface of the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints
  • Gottron's sign- Erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles. 
  • Mechanic’s hands- Rough, hyperkeratotic lines on the lateral and palmer areas of the fingers
  • Scalp erythema and hair loss
  • Facial rash- Confluent erythema in the malar distribution involving the cheeks, nasal bridge, and nasolabial folds
  • Nail fold changes
  • Flagellate erythema- Linear erythema on the upper back with pruritus
  • Poikiloderma- Mottled pattern of hyperpigmented and hypopigmented macules with telangiectasias
  • Cutaneous calcinosis- Accumulation of calcium deposits in the skin.

Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies. Electromyography will reveal features of myopathy. Histology will show perifascicular atrophy and immunohistochemical staining will reveal myxovirus resistance protein A, a sensitive and specific marker. 

Treatment of dermatomyositis is immunotherapy with high-dose glucocorticoids being the first line. Methotrexate can be started as the second line if the patient presents with severe weakness, other organ system involvement, or those with risk of steroid complications like patients with diabetes, osteoporosis, or postmenopausal women. Otherwise, second-line agents are only started in patients who do not show improvement after 2-4 months of treatment with prednisone or those who cannot be maintained on a low dose. Triple therapy with intravenous immunoglobulin or rituximab may be required. 

Note: Inclusion Body myositis is resistant to immunosuppressive medication 

Muscle biopsy findings in various inflammatory myositis are as follows-

Dermatomyositis Polymyositis Inclusion body myositis
Perimysial infiltrates Endomysial infiltrates  Endomysial infiltrates 
Perivascular infiltrates and perifascicular atrophy. Perivascular infiltrates    Perivascular infiltrates with amyloid inclusion bodies and rimmed vacuoles
CD4+ cellular infiltrates  CD8+ cellular infiltrates   CD8+ cellular infiltrates

questions.text: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is seen in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA) is not seen in prosthetic heart valves. It is associated with macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia.

MAHA refers to cell fragmentation that occurs in microcirculation. Microvascular lesions lead to luminal narrowing due to the deposition of fibrin and platelets. These produce shear stress that mechanically injures passing red cells. Hence, it is a type of non-immune hemolysis (Coombs-negative). On peripheral blood smear, schistocytes are seen.

Common causes of MAHA include:

  • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Vasculitis
  • Malignant hypertension
  • APLA syndrome
  • Drug-induced hemolysis
  • Eclampsia

questions.text:
A woman is brought to the casualty in an unconscious state with no signs of injury to the body. Her arterial blood gas analysis report reveals the following values. Among the given conditions, which of the following can lead to this clinical scenario?
  • pH- 7.32
  • pCO2- 36 mm Hg
  • HCO3- - 18 mEq/L
  • Sodium levels- 136 mEq/L
  • Chloride levels- 109 mEq/L
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the underlying disorder in this patient is metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap. Among the given options, diarrhea will lead to this scenario as diarrhea causes loss of bicarbonates.

The diagnosis can be arrived at by the following steps:

Step 1: A pH of 7.32 indicates acidosis.

Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 18 mmol/L

Step 3: Arterial pCO2 is within the normal range.

Therefore the patient has metabolic acidosis.

Step 4: Calculate the anion gap. 

Anion gap = Na+-(Cl-+HCO3-)

= 136-(109+18)

= 9, which is a normal anion gap.

Causes of normal anion gap acidosis (NAGMA) are:

  • Diarrhea
  • External pancreatic or small-bowel drainage
  • Ureterosigmoidostomy, jejunal loop, ileal loop
  • Drugs- Calcium chloride, magnesium sulfate, cholestyramine
  • Proximal and distal renal tubular acidosis
  • Potassium-sparing diuretics
  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers

Causes of high anionic gap acidosis (HAGMA) are:

  • Methanol poisoning
  • Uremia- renal failure
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Propylene glycol
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Ethanol poisoning
  • Salicylate poisoning

Other options:

Options A, C, and D: This will give rise to metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg

questions.text: All of the following favor a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Painless diarrhea or constipation does not favor the diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). 

IBS is a functional bowel disorder. It is characterized by abdominal pain or discomfort and altered bowel habits in the absence of detectable structural abnormalities. 

The ROME IV criteria are used to diagnose irritable bowel syndrome, which requires at least 3 days a month in the last 3 months associated with 2 or more of the following:

  • improvement in abdominal pain or discomfort with defecation
  • onset associated with a change in frequency of stool
  • and/or an onset accompanied by a change in form or appearance of stool

The onset of symptoms during a period of stress or emotional upset is a feature that supports a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with symptom onset at least 6 months before diagnosis.

questions.text: In which of the following condition is the pulse in the given image seen?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a water-hammer pulse (Corrigan’s pulse) which is seen in

  • Aortic regurgitation
  • Persistent ductus arteriosus
  • Arteriovenous fistula
  • Rupture of sinus of Valsalva

It is characterized by a rapid upstroke and a rapid downstroke. The rapid downstroke is due to the rapid run-off of blood into

  • the cavity of the left ventricle in AR
  • the pulmonary artery in PDA 
  • the veins in the case of AV fistula

 The rapid upstroke is due to increased stroke volume secondary to the hyperdynamic state.

Other options:

  • Aortic stenosis presents with pulsus parvus et tardus. It is seen as a low amplitude pulse that rises slowly and has a late peak.
  • HOCM presents with a bisferiens pulse. It is seen with a rapid upstroke to the first peak and a slower rise to the second peak.

Signs in aortic regurgitation:

Sign

Description

De Musset's sign

  Head nodding with each heartbeat

Collapsing/Water Hammer/Corrigan pulse

 It is a bounding pulse with rapid upstroke  and descent

Lighthouse sign

  Alternate flushing & blanching of the forehead

Landolfi’s sign

  Alternating constriction and dilation of the pupil

Becker’s sign

  Retinal artery pulsations

Quincke’s pulse

 Alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail
Rosenbach’s sign  Pulsation of liver
Gerhardt’s sign  Pulsation over the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly

Traube’s sign

 A pistol shot sound over femoral arteries

Durozeiz’s sign

 To-and-fro murmur over the femoral artery when lightly compressed with a stethoscope

Hill’s sign

 The systolic blood pressure of the lower limb exceeds that of the upper limb at least by 20mm Hg

Muller’s sign

Systolic pulsation of the uvula

questions.text:

  1. Giant cell arteritis
